Award.AwardTitle: Connecting Undergraduate Research with the Public through Innovative Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project connects a core curriculum science course taught in the Earth and Environmental Science department entitled, Science for Future Legislators, with the public through the growing of hydroponic food, air quality data collection using data eggs, and the use of touch foil technologies. Partnering with local businesses and libraries, the project team places touch foils on windows to engage the general public in understanding air quality data and the impact of land cover use and changes in air quality. A touch foil is a thin film that can be placed on any glass surface, for example a storefront window, which transforms that window into a large interactive touch surface (in essence transforming the window in a giant iPad). Using this guerilla science approach affords the general public the opportunity to learn about science in places where they would not expect to see science. The goal is to provide access to scientific data and analyses that are understandable and of interest to the general public in a way that does not require a visit to a museum or similar institution but in a place where the public takes a regular walk, visits, or spends their time. The project also engages non-science majors in growing produce hydroponically and learning how to conduct scientific research to investigate processes that maximize production. The produce is sold at a local market to help sustain the program and to help the community have access to fresh, healthy, and local food.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

The goals for this project are to improve student (1) understanding of the scientific research process and teaching them how to ask and evaluate testable research questions of data (2) understanding of the tools and technologies that scientists and environmental scientists use to collect and analyze data, (3) understanding of the importance of presenting and sharing the results of their research with the public by presenting the big ideas and concepts in an engaging and understandable way, (4) understanding that scientific research occurs over time, requires careful data collection, and often leads to new questions, (5) understanding that scientific research entails both data-driven inquiry (analysis of existing data sets) and the design of research experiments and that both are important to the scientific research process, and (6) science self-efficacy, interest, and motivation to learn more about science, which we hope will lead students to read the science section in the New York Times or actively seek out learning more about science content (i.e. reading Scientific American, Popular Science, watch NOVA) or even take additional university science level courses as one of their elective courses


Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this project revolves around five major aspects of the proposed work in which we will: (1) leverage emerging technologies to connect the work that is done in an undergraduate course with the general public, which, as far as we know is a unique component of a non-science major class. Further, the students’ work will not only support their own learning but will also be of interest at a local level because their research will report on the quality of air in areas where people work and live; (2) use touch foil technologies in strategic locations to engage citizens in science where they may not expect it. In other words, our goal is to provide access to scientific data and analyses that are understandable and of interest to the general public in a way that does not require them to visit a museum or similar institution but in a place where they regular walk, visit, or spend their time (or use a Guerilla Science Education approach); (3) provide a model for transforming a large, traditional, undergraduate non-science major course in which students are engaged in scientific research and analysis of data while learning to use emerging technologies; (4) make the data readily available for other students to analyze and develop a set of curriculum materials that other faculty can easily infuse into their own classes; and (5) engage students in a data-driven investigation and a research design process both of which are major components of the scientific research endeavor.
Broader ImpactThe number of non-science majors far outnumbers science majors at most universities, yet most research-based courses that have been developed has focused on STEM majors. However, non-science majors tend to have lower levels of science self-efficacy and lack skills regarding the scientific research process, yet often find themselves in need such skills (Laursen, Hunter, Seymour, Thiry, & Mellon, 2010). For example, more and more non-science careers are requiring scientific thinking and problem solving skills and more and more professions require the sorting of large amounts of data to identify patterns and trends (National Research Council, 2007, 2010). Further, a recent critical review published in Science on learning innovations in introductory science courses revealed that few comparison studies have been done at the college level on authentic research-based undergraduate laboratories (Ruiz-Primo, Briggs, Iverson, Talbot, & Sheppard, 2012). Our proposed work has a natural control group and satisfies the requirements put forth by Ruiz-Primo and colleagues for additional research and development that needs to be done to truly determine if innovations are improving student understanding of science.


Impacts

One of the goals of this project was to examine students ability to engage in scientific inquiry. College majors differed with respect to Scientific self-efficacy [F(2, 89) = 14.928, p < .0005]; business majors scored statistically significantly lower than education majors [4.36 v=5.870, t(74) = 10.440, p < .0005], and also statistically significantly lower than other majors [??= 5.942, t(65) = 8.948, p < .0005].  This fact was particularly interesting given that one of the goals of the course was to support education majors in improving their perceptions toward their ability to do scientific inquiry.The results suggest that the combination of a data-driven and open-ended inquiry projects impact students’ perceptions and their interest in ways that depend on their comfort level with science and major. This suggests that a course that is designed around both types of scientific inquiry may maximize the positive outcomes.
